PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ADERMANN; BURR; COWAN; HUNT; KATTER; NEWMAN; ROCHER
PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Discrimination against Women

To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Burr,Mr Cowan,Mr Hunt,Mr Katter,Mr Newman and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. Omega by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water enables hunter -killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a ''first strike'' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important U.S. military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .
3. Omega and other U.S. bases in Australia endanger, rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Hand and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government Will act to ratify the Convention of the Elimination of All Forms of Disrimination Against Women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fry,Mr Humphreys and Mrs Kelly.

PETITION.TITLE: Support Income
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned about the problems being created by high unemployment in Australia and the need for a long-term solution which will enable all who wish to work and are able to work to obtain work.

That your petitioners request that you consider the concept of a support income for all Australian residents as developed in the Basic Support Income proposal. This proposal has been designed to create an environment in which all who are able and wish to work can work. It also has a number of other features which will benefit the community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to RAAF Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of the Commonwealth submits:
That off-shore oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region constitutes a serious threat to the richest and most varied living system on earth.
Your petitioners request that your Honourable House will:
1. Prohibit oil exploration within the Great Barrier Reef Region,
2. Declare the entire Great Barrier Reef Region a Marine Park under the Federal Government's Great Barrier Marine Park Act 1975,
3. Provide the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority with the staff and resources for effective management of the Region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that Australia Council funding for the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has been entirely cut for 1983.

The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland has made an important contribution to the cultural and artistic life of the Australian community for the past eight years taking innovative and original theatre to sections of the community who would not normally attend live theatre performances.
The Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland is the only theatre company in Australia which consistently presents theatre of social comment and tours nationally every year.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will resolve to ask the Australia Council to reverse its decision in respect to the Popular Theatre Troupe of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That (a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and (b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining of Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state the quality of its scenery and natural environment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National Parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal Relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve should be declared a National Park.
Your Petitioners, therefore, Humbly Pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) accept the wishes of the petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the Government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sand mining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology and environment of the Island.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the Register of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 take into consideration the protection of the land.

3. That the Queensland Government has given approval to the sand mining of Moreton Island despite the advice of conservationists and despite the opposition of the majority of electors in the Moreton Region.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will request the Government to refuse export permits covering mineral sands mined on Moreton Island.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Exploitation of Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600.

We, your petitioners, humbly showeth: That permitting kangaroos to be commercially exploited when permissible cropping rates are unknown and the means of enforcing controls or protective laws are completely ineffective in this land , is allowing this unique animal to follow the path to rarity or extinction along which all wild animals have gone when subjected to exploitation in similar circumstances.
We Australians, have the right to see kangaroos in reasonable numbers on the landscape: We find the commercial slaughter of the kangaroo to be abhorrent and unjustified.
Commercialisation of wildlife should be stopped, particularly as exemplified by the kangaroo industry.
We your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will:
1. Ban the export of products made from kangaroos.
2. Take action to see that State governments prohibit the commercial killing of kangaroos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Marine Mammals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. Since the Australian Whale Protection Act 1980 provides for the banning of importation into Australia of all whale byproducts, and
2. the Prime Minister has stated that he and his Government support the international banning of whaling,
3. then consistent with (1) and (2), this Government should immediately legislate to ban the importation of all marine mammal byproducts, including the harp seal of Canada, and

4. through the Australian delegate in the United Nations General Assembly, the Prime Minister should state his Government's support for an international ban on the slaughter of any marine mammal for commercial reasons.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that consistent with legislation on whaling, this Government should ban the importation of marine mammal byproducts and support an international ban on slaughter of any marine mammal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Macedonian Language
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:
(1) That the Macedonian language be used by Government Departments in multi- lingual publications.
(2) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language as a Higher School Certificate (H.S.C.) subject in Secondary schools.
(3) That the petitioners urge the introduction of the Macedonian language in tertiary institutions and that a course be introduced at Monash University in the Deparment of Slavic Languages.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate action to implement the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Podiatry Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of podiatry service for lower fixed income members of the community.

Podiatry is an essential health service especially in preventing greater dependency of older people. It would be much more cost effective to maintain the mobility of older people through adequate and effective services than to force them into premature institutional care.

The fees for repeated podiatry consultations to provide essential ongoing care are well beyond the means of pensioners. Considering that Department of Veterans ' Affairs pensioners are entitled to podiatry care, and this scheme is already operating successfully, we strongly urge that this service be extended to cover all pensioners.

We believe this could be best achieved through including podiatry along with the existing concessions on the Health Care Cards. This would enable a flexible system of care through private practice, community health or rehabilitation services. It would also be essential in negotiations with the Podiatry Association to ensure assistance would be available to the household and those in institutions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Construction of Railway Overpass, Port Augusta, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australila respectfully showeth:

That the railway crossing situated approximately 5 kilomtres east of Port Augusta on Highway One (the main highway between Adelaide and all northern and western centres of South Australia and continuing through to Western Australia) has once again been the sight of an horrendous accident.

This accident has caused two, possibly three fatalities. Previous requests have been made by the City Council of Port Augusta for the construction of an overpass, so that this section of the highway no longer presents a danger to the motoring public and those involved in driving trains over this crossing.
Permission for construction of this overpass has previously been refused and the situation has now become critical.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and approve construction of an overpass at this fatally dangerous railway crossing to avoid further loss of life.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Attendant Care Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth the need for the immediate introduction of an Attendant Care Allowance for Disabled people who need assistance with aspects of daily living.
This allowance will enable disabled people to live in the community.
It should be in the form of a benefit paid directly to the disabled person enabling him/her to employ and train the attendant of his/her own choice.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mackay Directory Assistance Centre
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Mackay respectfully showeth:
That the intention of Telecom Australia to close the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre will:
downgrade telephone services to Mackay and district.
deprive customers of a personalized reliable telephone service.
reduce job opportunities in the area.
increase the likelihood of the eventual closure of the exchange.
We the undersigned believe that Telecom Australia has a social reponsibility to provide a sound, reliable, personalised telephone system.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the honourable House will call on the Government to intervene to stop Telecom's proposed closure of the Mackay Directory Assistance Centre.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beddall,Mr Cross,Mr Humphreys,Mr Keogh and Mr Lindsay.

PETITION.TITLE: Scullin Health Centre, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Australian Capital Territory respectfully showeth:

That being mindful of the important role that community health centres play in the provision of health care for citizens of the Australian Capital Territory and of the vital part played by Scullin Health Centre in the provision of Health care in Central and Southern Belconnen in the electorate of Fraser are distressed at the uncertainty over the possible closure or disruption of current medical, paramedical and anciliary services at that Centre.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will prevail upon the Minister for Health to take no action that will in any way affect the continuity of operation of all current services at the Scullin Health Centre or diminish services to patients, professional or other staff at that Centre until the report of the Task Force on the structure of the Capital Territory Health Commission has been published and the community served by that Centre has been fully consulted.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Transcontinental (North-South) Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of certain citizens of the Northern Territory of Australia shows:

1. That the Commonwealth of Australia and the State of South Australia entered into an agreement on 7th December, 1907 requiring the Commonwealth of Australia to construct the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway from Darwin to South Australia;
2. That the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway has not yet been constructed ;
3. That the construction of the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway is the linchpin for the further development of the Northern Territory of Australia;

4. That the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway will provide employment through construction work, steel production and manufacturing and it will assist in ensuring the defence and security of Northern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth of Australia commence and complete construction of the Transcontinental (North-South) Railway at an early date.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the citizens of the City of Woodville and supported by the citizens of South Australia, being deeply concerned over the threat of closure of the Woodville Plant of General Motors-Holden's, respectfully show:
1. That the management of General Motors-Holden's has failed over a period of more than two (2) years to give any assurances that the Woodville Plant would continue in operation.
2. That a recent statement attributed to the GMH Managing Director, quote:
'The overall objective of our South Australian rationalisation plan has been to eliminate all productive activities on the Woodville site' end of quote.
This statement has not been refuted.
3. That the elimination of the Woodville Plant will cause enormous social dislocation, hardship and misery to the citizens of Woodville and South Australia.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Parliament of Australia will condemn this callous disregard for the citizens of Woodville and South Australia, and do all in its power to force General Motors-Holden's to retain its operation at the Woodville Plant.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes-
(a) the suggestion of thousands of petitioners that the day of 26 January of each year is the appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day, and

DEBATE.TITLE: BRISBANE CITY COUNCIL PUBLIC BUS SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keogh Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) condemns the failure of the Queensland Government to include funds for the Brisbane City Council Public Bus System in their submission to the Federal Government under the urban public transport funding available from the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program, and
(2) calls on the Government to act urgently, by using every means at its disposal, to compel the Queensland Government to resubmit a proposal which includes the Brisbane City Council Bus System.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes that-

(a) many small businesses have superannuation funds which they wish to invest legitimately in long-term property investment and have income exempt from Income Tax under paragraph 23 (f) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, and

(b) the Commissioner of Taxation allows large business superannuation funds to invest in long-term property investments, and in exercising his discretion, refuses many small business funds the right to do so, and
(2) calls on the Government to-
(a) request the Commissioner of Taxation to end any discrimination against small business funds;
(b) publish a clear set of rules and guidelines for investment in all superannuation funds, and
(c) explain reasons for any different rules between types of funds under paragraph 23 (f).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) condemns, as unsound, the monetarist economic strategies on which the previous Government's policies were based, and
(2) confirms its support for a macroeconomic strategy based on growth and equitable redistribution of wealth and income.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes that-
(a) the dissident Soviet physicist, Andrei Sakharov remains in internal exile in the closed city of Gorki in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) expresses its concern at the-
(a) price cuts being enforced on the Pilbara iron ore producers, Hamersley Iron and Mount Newman by Japanese steel mills; and
(b) inaction by the previous Government on this crucial matter.
(2) supports the Western Australian Premier, Mr Brian Burke, in his negotiations with Japanese producers, and
(3) urges the Australian Government to provide active support to Australian mineral producers in their negotiations with the Japanese.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) Applauds the excellent rescue work presently being carried out by the Amberley RAAF helicopter and Caribou pilots in the Dirranbandi, St George, Injune, Quilpie, Charleville and Roma area following the heaviest May rain in south-west Queensland since 1890.
(2) calls on the Government to grant all the disaster assistance that is available to help the people of this part of the Electoral Division of Maranoa to recover from this great flood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) notes the statement on Tuesday, 24 May, by the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, that he intended to use Queensland taxpayers' money in an advertising campaign opposing the proposed referendum to limit early elections, and
(2) condemns the Premier's assumption that it is appropriate to use Queensland' s public money for his own party political purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) recognises and puts on record the dedicated and momentous work of Professor Graeme Clark and those associated with him in the development of the bionic ear which means so much to so many deaf people, and
(2) calls on the Government to ensure that adequate funding for this development is maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House strongly supports the case for Hobart to be the location of the proposed National Maritime Museum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses-
(1) its dismay at the Government's attack on community savings;
(2) its disappointment that the Economic Summit has proved to be an illusion;
(3) its condemnation of the Prime Minister's leadership and lack of forthrightness, and
(4) its wish that the Labor Party backbench assert its authority and drag the Government back on to the rails.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) condemns the Government for abolishing the Bicentennial Water Resources Program, and
(2) calls on the Government to continue funding allocated by the previous Government for the Mitchell River dam project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to correct a personal misrepresentation.
—The honourable member, having claimed to have been misrepresented, may proceed.

—I refer to an article in the Australian this morning on page 7, entitled 'How a former minister put his foot right in it'. I believe that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) might also see some misrepresentation in this article. It alleges that I was trapped unawares by the Minister yesterday when I asked a question about the bionic ear. Indeed, it was the journalist who put his foot in it. Journalists sometimes do that, Mr Speaker. I was misrepresented on four counts. The first is that I am old fashioned enough to believe that Question Time is a time when specific answers to questions might be obtained. Secondly, I have been misrepresented because, as this House will know, since 1972, no matter what government has been in power, I have consistently fought the case for the deaf, whether the government was discomfited or not. Thirdly, I knew that the Minister had in his possession a model of the bionic ear. I had seen it and I wanted the House to see it. I knew that no politics would be involved in the matter because this development has gone on over a number of governments and a number of Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: I was misrepresented, fourthly, because the information was valuable to me in that I have a son who is scheduled to have this operation. I wanted to know, and thousands of deaf people wanted to know, whether surgery had been commenced again, as it had been discontinued, and also whether Melbourne is the only centre in which it is being performed. The Minister knew this because I asked him to inquire. He had to make inquiries to give a specific answer to a specific question. He gave me the answer, something which he could not have done off the cuff. It was good news to many unfortunate deaf people. So, far from putting my foot in it, I knew what I was doing. I thank the Minister for his answer. We got the answer we sought. I believe it was a service to the long-neglected deaf who have had little consideration from a number of governments over the years.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The concern and distress of millions of Australians whose superannuation investment planning has been destroyed by the Government's decision on the future tax liability of lump sum payments.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the first issue which has given rise to public concern about this Government. It is not the second, it is not the third nor, indeed, is it the fourth. It is just one more in a long list of acts of incompetence which already is becoming a hallmark of this Government, incompetence which does not just embarrass the Government but which hurts millions of Australians. In the short time available to me there are three essential points I will make about the increase in tax on lump sum superannuation. First, the decision strikes at literally millions of Australians . Secondly, the Government's handling of the matter has been abject and inept. Thirdly, the decision is just another example of this Government's growing record of deceit. Let there be no doubt, the Liberal and National parties would never be so inept, never be so callous, in the policy making processes relating to the savings of the Australian people. As I said, the Government's handling of the increase in taxation on lump sum superannuation is just another example of its incompetence. But it is more than that. The Government has taken an impulsive, ill-considered decision without any consideration for the human impact it will have on millions of individual Australians. It has not thought out its proposals. It has not examined the details. It had not consulted representatives of the superannuation and life insurance industries until Tuesday, five days after the decision was announced. It still has not consulted the trade union movement, when its prices and incomes agreement commits the Government to consultations on this and other issues before decisions are taken.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday we learnt from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that details of the changes probably would be put before Cabinet next Monday-probably, but not definitely. Perhaps they will, perhaps they will not. We do not know; nor does the Treasurer . But above all, nor do the 1.8 million Australians who are in superannuation schemes. They do not know and neither do their families. They are left in a state of total uncertainly and total insecurity. Yesterday the Treasurer was asked some very straightforward questions on the impact of his proposal by my colleague the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman). He was asked whether the increased tax on lump sum superannuation would affect widows on the death of their husbands. He was asked whether it would affect people forced to retire through an accident, for example, paraplegics. He was asked whether it would affect itinerant workers. He was asked whether the sole exemption to the measure was registered redundancy payments. A Treasurer who had taken a decision after careful consultation, after careful thought-indeed, a Treasurer who cared about Australians-could answer a question like that. But what reply did we get? It was that he did not know. The cases that were raised by the honourable member for Mitchell were not unusual; they represented common everyday situations, but the Treasurer did not know how they would be affected by his policy. Why did he not know? Because this measure has just not been thought through. No wonder there is widespread concern. No wonder many hundreds of thousands of Australians are suddenly worried. At the beginning of last week they had been planning their future on the basis of their superannuation. By the end of the week their plans had been thrown into confusion. They are worried about unemployment. They are worried about high interest rates. They are worried about health insurance. Now, to add to these worries, they are worried about their superannuation, about how to plan their livelihood when they retire.

These are not the rich. They are not just company directors or professional people. Lump sum superannuation is, to quote a spokesman for the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Australian Workers Union, the only chance workers have had to free themselves from loan sharks. More than 40 per cent of all wage and salary earners, or about 1.8 million people, are in superannuation schemes. Add to that number their wives and children and it can be seen that this measure affects almost half of the Australian population. Now some of them will not take their superannuation in a lump sum but most will. About 83 per cent of participants in superannuation schemes in the private sector take their payments in a lump sum. The message of the Treasurer to them is simple-he has not thought through his proposal. He does not know what he is doing. Again, this is a government that is showing a callous disregard for middle Australia.

Let me offer two examples to show just how careless, in every sense of the word , this Government has been. Let us take the case of a serviceman aged 45 years who is required to retire from the armed forces. He has lived in different parts of Australia. He may have lived overseas. Certainly, he will not have been in one place long enough to be able to buy a house, and he will have no immediate job prospects. He must depend on his lump sum superannuation payment not only to buy a house but also, in many cases, to set up a business, to give himself an occupation. Suddenly, at a stroke, he will lose 30 per cent of his future lump sum payment. In future it will be much harder for him to buy a house. It could well be impossible for him to set up a business. How is he now to provide for his future and his family?

Let us consider a second example, and there is a plethora of them-from those mentioned in the question of the honourable member for Mitchell yesterday to thousands of others. Let us take the example of a shopkeeper who has worked all his life, has rented accommodation and has not taken out any form of superannuation. Suddenly he decides that he needs superannuation. He takes out a highly geared package contributing over, say, 10 years a sum which normally might have taken 30 years to contribute. Thus, he has contributed at three times the normal rate. What we do know is that the new tax relates only to contributions made from the date of the bringing down of the mini-Budget. Let us say that he has contributed for two years already. When he takes the lump sum payment he will be taxed at, say, the 30 per cent rate in respect of eight years ' payments. So his retirement plan has now been thrown into total confusion. His savings commitments, to reach his retirement target, are no longer sufficient but he will be unable to make alternative plans because the Treasurer does not know how such a scheme would be affected. As he indicated yesterday, he has not given it a thought. I suppose that it should surprise no one to learn that this Government does not care about such people as shopkeepers. They are the sort of people who would never even be considered when issuing invitations to a summit. They are just two examples. As I said, there are thousands more and none of these examples and none of these people have been given consideration by the Government. They have been callously ignored and these measures announced by the --

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the bankruptcy rate under you.
—You talk about what we did. We were in government for decades and we never did this. You are the one who did it and you have not thought through the consequences or the hardship imposed.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will address the Chair. The Minister for Defence Support will cease interjecting constantly.
—He is an intellectual cripple, Mr Speaker, and he shows no regard for others who suffer hardship in life.
—Mr Speaker, I find the term offensive.
—The Minister finds the term offensive. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw the remark.

—Yes. I will withdraw. I said that such people had been callously ignored. The measures announced by the Treasurer are heartless and the Government used a sledge hammer when careful, sympathetic planning was needed. No one would deny that our system of social security is imperfect. There are problems, financial challenges and concern about the rising burden of pension payments, but the solutions must be carefully considered. Decisions must be made after, not before, due consideration has been given to the hardship those solutions may inflict on Australians. A further aspect of this whole sorry exercise is of very great concern not just to the Opposition but to all Australians. It is the re-emergence of our old bogey, Hawkespeak; the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says one thing but really means the opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: This fundamental change to our social security system was not foreshadowed in the Prime Minister's policy speech. It was not foreshadowed in Labor's national recovery and reconstruction plan. It was not foreshadowed in the Prime Minister' s numerous pre-election speeches. It was not foreshadowed in the hours and hours of Press interviews he gave. In other words, Australians had no warning that this was coming. What is worse, any suspicions that some may have had were quickly allayed after the election. Not one but several newspapers reported on 16 April that the Prime Minister had stated that there would be no increase in tax on lump sum superannuation. Yesterday the Prime Minister told the House that these reports were without substance. Later in the day, he described these reports as 'speculation'. Maybe they were. The Prime Minister clearly knew these reports were inaccurate. Why then did he give those millions of Australians a false sense of security? Why did he let them believe that their nest eggs were safe when he knew they were not? Why then did he allow this cruel deception to go on? A responsible Prime Minister would have denied these allegedly false reports immediately. Our Prime Minister did not. But what he did do bears reading to the House. According to the Secretary of the New South Wales Labour Council, Mr Barry Unsworth, the Prime Minister told the Australian Council of Trade Unions Executive during the National Economic Summit Conference that there would be no increase in tax on lump sum superannuation. Mr Unsworth told Nationwide two nights ago:

I was at the Summit as a member of the ACTU Executive, it was reported to the full executive by officers of the ACTU that after discussions with the Prime Minister and others that there was no fear about the likelihood of the Government to tax lump sum superannuation payments. That undertaking, as we all took it, has been broken prospectively.

The Prime Minister denies such a commitment, so whom are we to believe-Mr Barry Unsworth, a respected member of the ALP and the trade union movement, or the Prime Minister? Could the Prime Minister have misled the ACTU at his Summit, at the meeting which made consensus a part of Australia's political rhetoric? The fact is that, once again, Australians have been cruelly misled, particularly middle Australia. It trusted the Government to give help. The Government has taken away the home loan interest rebate, the health insurance rebate, the pension of many old people, the hope of tax cuts, and now middle Australia has been told without warning to pay 30 per cent tax on lump sum superannuation payments-without any warning, without any preparation.

As I said early in this statement, the Liberal Party and the National Party would never be so callous or so inept in the policy making processes relating to the savings of Australian people. At the very least, we should be considering, not the sort of review about which the Treasurer was talking-a review of what? He does not even know what it is; how can he review it? It would be some form of retreat from that review on Monday; there is no doubt about that. We should have at least an all-party committee to examine the matter, because this is a shameful act from a deceitful Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The address of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was made with all the sincerity of a Mississippi gambler . What a squalid opportunist he is. No objection to this measure was mentioned in these terms in the reply of the Leader of the Opposition just two days ago, no mention of it in these terms at all. Indeed, I do not think that there was any mention of it. Where has he discovered all this indignation all of a sudden? Of course, it is mock indignation. The other question which needs to be addressed, apart from the obvious breakdown in integrity by the Leader of the Opposition in terms of his own view of this measure, is: Why was this matter not proposed by the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard )? He is the spokesman on these matters. He is the shadow Treasurer. Why did he not do it?

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clearly within my portfolio. The honourable member for Bennelong has the shadow portfolio. Why did he not do it? I will say why he did not do it: It is because he believes in the measure.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why he did not do it.
—Order! There is far too much interjection. I ask the House to come to order.

—The honourable member for Bennelong believes in the measure; that is why he did not do it. It has been made obvious and clear over time that he and Senator Chaney would have liked to have got this measure through the last Liberal Cabinet, but they could not do so because of the lack of any sense of justice, fairness or integrity in that Cabinet, and quite obviously it is here.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, let us look at the extravagance in the terms of this matter of public importance. The Leader of the Opposition talks about 'concern and distress', that 'investment planning has been destroyed by the government's decision'. Destroyed, in a measure which has no retrospective quality about it? No entitlement up to last Thursday evening will be touched. That is the commitment that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave, and that is the commitment which the Leader of the Opposition would not recognise. The commitment was that there would be no retrospective element to any changes. What we are seeing is a gradual change in the favoured tax treatment of superannuation which will accrue into the future.

Let me quote what the former Treasurer and the former Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr Street), said when they issued a statement on occupational superannuation in September 1979:
There does seem to be very wide measure of agreement on one point-namely, that the current framework of legislation is in need of considerable reform.

Of course it is in need of considerable reform. That is because we have a major anomaly in the social security and tax system of this nation. There is a $2,000m contribution to superannuation each year to provide for people on income in retirement. That is the purpose of it. Over time the habit has been that most people take their superannuation benefits as lump sums, not for the original purpose and intent of securing a retirement income. Then there is a problem in that people have been arranging their affairs in such a way as not to attract income to that sum-
Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, can I get some protection from the drones on the back benches?
—Order! The House will come to order.

—Then we see people doing what is called double dipping-using their lump sums and arranging their affairs in such a way that they do not attract income and then collect the old age pension. What has not been addressed is the fact that 60 per cent of the Australian work force have no superannuation benefits available to them. Forty per cent-a minority-have. The Leader of the Opposition is apparently arguing that the 60 per cent without superannuation should continue to subsidise the superannuations of the 40-odd per cent with superannuation and then, after having subsidised them to secure a retirement income, approve of the fact that they can then go and line up for the age pension of which 60 per cent of the Australian work-force again have to pay their share. Quite obviously, there is a clear need for reform. An article reporting the Chairman of the Australian Mutual Provident Society Ltd, Mr David Anderson, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government's move last week to alter the taxation of superannuation benefits was 'wholly understandable'. The Chairman of the AMP Society, Mr David Anderson, said yesterday. Addressing policy holders at the life offices annual meeting Mr Anderson also said that the Government's moves would improve Australia's national capacity to meet the rapidly growing public cost of age pensions. It seems to us wholly understandable that the Government is moving the community's framework of retirement provisions towards pensions.
We, ourselves, have expressed concern at the drain on public resources through what has become known as double dipping and through dissipation of superannuation funds as employees change jobs.

That is the view of someone who does not normally endorse the policies of my party but, of course, it is a sane and sensible view on the need to meet the problem of the substantial demographic shift which is taking place in Australia. We have an aging and growing population and over time the cost of securing people in their retirement will be a very heavy impost on the Budget to be borne disproportionately by the work force. There has to be a time when changes can take place.

Let me make a number of things clear about the nature of the change which has taken place. The Government believes that it would have been unfair to have attempted to tax lump sum superannuation on a retrospective basis. It made it clear that it would touch no element of retrospectivity whatsoever. The proposal has no element of retrospectivity about it. The gradual and moderate accrual of benefits from this time will be subject to tax at the standard rate, which is roughly 30c in the dollar. To illustrate graphically the fairness of the Government's measure I compare the cost to revenue in this year of the subsidy to superannuation, which is $2,000m a year, with the savings to revenue in year one of $15m. That is a cost of $2,000m compared with a saving of $15m.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much--
—In year two a cost of $2,000m--
—What about the indexed bonds?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, am I continually to be abused by the honourable member for Mitchell and the drone beside him, the honourable member for Braddon?
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will cease interjecting. The House will come to order.

—In the second year the cost to the public purse is $2,000m. The saving to revenue is $70m. It will take years to build up to the maximum saving of $420m. Honourable members should compare the $2,000m subsidy with the eventual savings to revenue of $400m. That demonstrates the moderation of the Government's proposal and the essential fairness of it. Compare $2,000m in year one against a $15m saving. So much for this phoney opportunist claim by the Leader of the Opposition that this destroys people's retirement planning.
—He is lying all the time.
—It is absolute nonsense and bunkum and the Leader of the Opposition knows it.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Denison to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw. The Government is a lying government. It has broken its promises. Liar!
—Order! I ask the honourable member to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw. The Government is lying.
—Order! I ask the honourable member to withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw. You ought to have a lie detector test. You could be called polygraph Paul.
—I warn the honourable member for Denison.
—Do not worry about him, Mr Deputy Speaker. He has got the political morals of an alley cat.
—You are the world's only two-faced ferret and you know it.
—The honourable member for Denison is provoking the Chair. I will not tolerate any more insubordination in this matter.

—The other essential element of this scheme is that potential retirees can take the option of not paying any tax on the lump sum at all by purchasing an annuity. The Government, in the last couple of days, has been meeting with the life offices and the superannuation funds to establish ways in which annuities can be offered on a very attractive basis so that over time we will see people securing a retirement income by using the lump sum, which will not be subject to tax should they exercise the right to purchase an annuity.

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing which was addressed in my statement last Thursday was the question of portability. We have indicated that anybody leaving one superannuation arrangement and going to another will not again be taxed on any lump sum and that lump sum can be transferred on a portable basis. As well as that the more general question of portability is under consideration. So if we are to do anything substantial about the problem of providing a retirement income for people, of dealing with the problems of the greying and aging of the Australian population and the future heavy cost to the public purse of securing people in their retirement, this would be the most equitable, sensible and fair way to do it. There is no retrospective element and no diminution of any accrued benefit before last Thursday evening. So anybody who has been in a superannuation scheme for 10, 15 or 20 years will have no benefits touched. But in the future, as they gradually accrue benefits, they will be subject to taxation. In no way can it be then assumed that, as the Leader of the Opposition asserts, this in some way destroys the capacity of people to plan their retirement.

I need to get the Government's proposals back into a clear perspective. I am just aghast at the fact that the Leader of the Opposition saw fit not to mention these changes in his reply on Tuesday to the Government's economic statement. Because there has been some Press speculation, he has raced into this Parliament to make a noise about it. Obviously the Leader of the Opposition is motivated by the noises from the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. Its members are worrying about whether their lump sums in excess of $250,000 will be taxed; that is their concern. The Leader of the Opposition is batting for the retirees who will receive very high levels of lump sums. Let me just say this about the Australian Federation of Air Pilots and those pilots who have made some expressions about this matter: If the Australian Federation of Air Pilots should decide to take industrial action on this issue it will be a triumph of greed over need. This Government will tolerate none of those objections from these people who have been very handsomely looked after in their employment and who receive a massive subsidy from the public purse towards their retirement. We cannot make the 60 per cent of people who do not have any superannuation benefit continually subsidise the 40 per cent who have. We cannot do so on the basis that those capital sums are used to pay off houses, buy overseas trips, boats and the like, and then back up for the age pension. We cannot ask the same people, the small people who have no superannuation, to continue shelling out their taxation to keep people who, in retirement, receive massive lump sums.

The whole purpose of superannuation and the public subsidy of superannuation has long gone off the rails and it has to come back. We are bringing it back in a responsible and sane way. It would not have been too much to hope that the Opposition in this Parliament would have supported us in that measure. Up until this time we have had no indication that it had any motive other than to support us in this measure. In the backgrounding of journalists after my statement last Thursday, the indication of the Opposition was that it would support this measure both in the Parliament and outside. Now we find that, because of a few noises coming from the airline pilots and others, the Leader of the Opposition is trying to exploit the situation. All I can say is that he will not be in this Parliament as Leader of the Opposition for long.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE BROADCASTING OF PARLIAMENTARY PROCEEDINGS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matters be referred to the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings for inquiry and report:
(a) the televising of the proceedings of the Houses of the Parliament and their committees in the present and the new Parliament House; and
(b) the radio broadcasting of the proceedings of the Houses of the Parliament and their committees including the continuous and simultaneous broadcasting of both Houses.
(2) That the committee, for any purposes related to this inquiry, have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(3) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting its concurrence.

Last year both Houses of the Parliament agreed to motions referring to the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings: The matter of the televising of the proceedings of the House of the Parliament and their committees in the new Parliament House, and the continuous and simultaneous radio broadcasting of both Houses of Parliament. The Committee's inquiry had not begun when the election was called and the Parliament dissolved. Reactivating the reference provides an opportunity to expand the Committee's terms to allow for a more extensive inquiry to cover televising proceedings in the existing Parliament House and the broadcasting of extracts on radio and television. As honourable members would be aware, the expansion of the terms was suggested to the Government by the Acting Clerk, with the support of Mr Speaker. The Government is happy to agree that the Committee should examine these matters now . Furthermore, the Government would be pleased if the Committee were, in settling its priorities, to consider reporting first on televising the present Parliament. The Committee will now have the benefit of experience of the National Economic Summit Conference, where mobile TV apparatus was used successfully. Although last year the Senate Standing Orders Committee found that television costs could not be justified for the present building, the Government believes the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings Committee is the right forum for exploring these questions further. The Government looks forward to learning of the Committee's views.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: — First of all, I welcome the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his new role as stand-in Leader of the House. I presume it is a temporary role. I do not know whether it is because the Leader of the House (Mr Young) has decided to stand aside while the royal commission inquires into his leaks and the comments he may have made regarding the Combe affair. If so, I think it would be a very appropriate course of action for him to take. On the two parts of point (1) of the motion I wish to draw a couple of remarks to the attention of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: The first is that yesterday, when we were dealing with another matter pertaining to closed circuit television, I mentioned what I see as a very considerable inconvenience to members from the arc lights necessary for televising proceedings. That is apart from the substantive issue. I hope that in the report that this Joint Committee brings back to us we will have some descriptive analysis of the extent to which both the heat and the brilliance will interfere with what I described yesterday as the proper debating chamber function here. I believe that if the televising of proceedings is as it was at the time of the Joint Sitting back in 1974 all members of this place will find that after a time it is not particularly comfortable. For that reason, if for no other, I think that many honourable members will want to consider very seriously any recommendations that flow from the Joint Committee.

The second point I want to make, in respect of point (1) (b) of the motion, is that I think all of us have become accustomed to hearing extracts of House of Commons debates during news broadcasts and news commentaries. Of course, these are not subject to our Australian broadcasting laws. It seems that in Australia, because of the way in which our broadcasting of the proceedings of the Houses of Parliament is now regulated, broadcasting of such extracts from the Australian Parliament is not permissible. Whether, therefore, there should be an extension to the Australian scene of the present House of Commons and other parliamentary forum practices so that we can broadcast from our own proceedings is a matter that might properly be considered by the Joint Committee. Proceedings not only from the House of Commons but also occasionally from the United States are broadcast on the Australian broadcasting stations and in my view the same facility should be available from our Australian Senate and House of Representatives as from those chambers.

In the course of its inquiry, I hope the Joint Committee will take as possible an extension of the second term of reference. The Opposition did not specifically consider moving an amendment to that effect but perhaps the Deputy Prime Minister will take the suggestion on board. PROCTEXT.PARA: Suspension of Sessional Order

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the House (Mr Young) has had to travel to Darwin and therefore, in my role as temporary Leader of the House, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the sessional order of 4 May 1983 amending Standing Order 48A, relating to the adjournment of the House, be suspended for the sitting of the House on 23 August 1983.

Briefly, as is known, the Budget will be introduced on 23 August 1983. At present Standing Order 48A provides that the House will adjourn at 6 p.m. on a Tuesday. In order that the Budget, as is customary, can be introduced on Tuesday , 23 August, at 8 p.m., it is necessary to suspend the Standing Order which relates to the provisional adjournment. In other words, we will go back to the former rule 48A to provide that the House will be suspended at the normal time in the evening. This merely will enable the Budget, as would be expected by all, to be introduced at a time when the nation will be able to hear it and the press will be able to report upon it. It will have all the elements of secrecy until 8 p.m. on the day.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move :

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Ombudsman Act 1976, which came into operation in July 1977, was the result of bipartisan support for the proposal that there should be an ombudsman with jurisdiction over the administrative actions of Commonwealth Government agencies . Legislation to establish the office was an initiative of the Whitlam Labor Government, carried forward by the succeeding Government. In a similar way the present Bill exemplifies the bipartisan approach to ombudsman legislation; it is substantially the same as the Ombudsman Amendment Bill, introduced in the last Parliament by the previous Government, which was designed in accordance with recommendations of the Administrative Review Council, a statutory advisory body set up under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.

This Government has undertaken to be closely guided by the Administrative Review Council in further developing the administrative review system. The present Bill instances that undertaking and provides a development and expansion of the Ombudsman's role. The Bill has two purposes. First, it will create and confer on the Commonwealth Ombudsman a statutory office of Defence Force Ombudsman. Secondly, it will amend the Ombudsman Act in the light of operational experience to date.
Defence Force Ombudsman

The proposal to create a Defence Force Ombudsman, with jurisdiction to investigate administrative actions related to or arising from a person's service in the Defence Force, had its origin in the platform of the last Labor Government. Legislation to establish the office lapsed in 1975, though an interim office of Defence Force Ombudsman has continued to operate in the Department of Defence since that time. In 1979 the previous Government requested that the Administrative Review Council examine the proposal. Its report was tabled on 4 July 1981 and the present Bill reflects its conclusions.

The Bill proposes that the office of Defence Force Ombudsman, although being established within the Ombudsman Act as a complement to the Ombudsman's general jurisdiction, should be identifiable and distinct. In particular, the Bill provides for a Deputy Ombudsman (Defence Force) to be designated to perform the day to day work of the Defence Force jurisdiction. Recognising the importance of this new position for the defence forces, before a Deputy Ombudsman is approved or designated for the Defence Force jurisdiction, the Prime Minister will consult with the Minister for Defence. Whilst the creation of the new statutory Defence Force jurisdiction will result in some extra costs, notably the salary- approximately $50,350 per annum-of the new Deputy Ombudsman, establishing the jurisdiction within the Ombudsman's office will avoid administrative duplication and ensure that it is effectively exercised at minimum cost.

The creation of a statutory office of Defence Force Ombudsman will provide an important advance in the conditions of employment for Service members. Servicemen and women differ from most other Australians in that their relations with their employers can extend into almost every aspect of their lives. It is in the nature of Defence Force service that members do not have the advantage of external grievance mechanisms typical in civil employment. With the creation of a Defence Force Ombudsman an independent avenue for the review of grievances will be established.

The Defence Force Ombudsman's function is to investigate, either on complaint being made or of his own motion, administrative actions related to or arising from a person's service in the Defence Force. Although most complaints will come from current or former service members, other persons, such as their dependants, will also be able to lodge complaints if they are affected by actions which are within the Defence Force Ombudsman's jurisdiction.

In recognition of Service members' special position, the Defence Force Ombudsman's jurisdiction is defined by service in the Defence Force, whereas the Commonwealth Ombudsman is excluded from investigating matters arising in Commonwealth civilian employment. There are, however, some exclusions from the proposed jurisdiction which parallel exclusions from the Commonwealth Ombudsman' s existing jurisdiction. In addition, the Defence Force Ombudsman is excluded from investigating action taken in the conduct of disciplinary proceedings, and action relating to the grant or refusal of most honours and awards though not, for example, campaign medals.

Review by the Defence Force Ombudsman will complement, rather than compete with , existing internal redress procedures: For effective management in the Defence Force, officers should usually hear and have the first opportunity to remedy the grievances of those under their command.

The legislation applies most of the procedural provisions in the Ombudsman Act to the Defence Force Ombudsman, such as those concerning the conduct of investigations. As well, transitional provisions in the Bill provide for the transfer to the statutory office of Defence Force Ombudsman of any unfinished business of the interim non-statutory office.
Other Provisions

The remainder of the Bill makes a number of amendments to the Ombudsman Act based on the Ombudsman's operational experience to date, drawing on the review by the Administrative Review Council. The full report of that review was tabled in the House on 23 September last year. The main theme to these amendments is that the Ombudsman, an independent officer with the statutory formal duties and powers essential to vigorous investigation and reporting of defective administration, should normally operate less formally than is appropriate for other administrative review mechanisms, such as courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Accordingly, several amendments are made which give the Ombudsman greater discretion and flexibility by modifying formal procedural requirements in the Act. In particular, the Bill includes amendments which:
Recognise that the Ombudsman may accept and resolve oral complaints-unless there is a need to investigate formally;
simplify the Ombudsman's discretion not formally to investigate certain complaints;
streamline the requirements for the Ombudsman to notify the Minister and agency head of his decision whether to investigate a complaint; and
give legislative backing to the Ombudsman's practice of making informal inquiries.
The last amendment will also clarify that the Ombudsman may inquire informally to establish that a matter is within his jurisdiction before investigating formally.

In amendments which are similarly to facilitate his role in encouraging better and more accessible administration, the Bill also gives the Ombudsman greater discretion to disseminate information or comments on his investigations to Commonwealth agencies, the Parliament, other people with an interest in the outcome of investigations-for example, parliamentarians-and, where special circumstances so warrant, to the public at large.
Other amendments variously strengthen or widen the Ombudsman's role in line with developing practice and the intention of the Ombudsman legislation. These amendments will:

Provide a sounder statutory basis for co-operative investigation by the Commonwealth Ombudsman and his counterparts in the States and Northern Territory where both Commonwealth and State or Territory activities or undertakings are involved;
empower the Federal Court to determine issues that may arise in relation to the Ombudsman's powers and jurisdiction;
expand the circumstances in which the Ombudsman can cause matters to come before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; and

clarify certain doubts that have arisen regarding the Ombudsman's jurisdiction over particular types of action, including administrative action leading up to or following action by a Minister, and jurisdiction over particular types of Commonwealth bodies.
More detailed information on the provisions of the Bill is set out in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

This Bill makes amendments, primarily to the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981, which complement the provisions of the Ombudsman Amendment Bill 1983.

The Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 in part provides for the independent investigation by the Ombudsman of complaints against the Australian Federal Police. The Act provides a role for the Ombudsman in relation to complaints, substantially similar to that in the Ombudsman Act 1976. Parallel amendment of both Acts is desirable to ensure basic uniformity in the Ombudsman' s powers and duties in relation to complaints.

The explanatory memorandum which has been circulated provides more detailed information on the manner in which amendments to the Ombudsman Act have been reflected in this specific complaints jurisdiction. I commend the Bill to the House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to a new River Murray Waters Agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia for the control and management of certain water resources of the River Murray system. The new Agreement is set out in the Schedule to this Bill.

From the earliest days of Federation, the Commonwealth has demonstrated a strong interest in River Murray matters, initially reflecting its concern for interstate trade implications of river traffic, but even more important more recently, a recognition of the national importance of water conservation and associated land development based on the River Murray. In fact, River Murray problems, which were already claiming a good deal of attention from 1880 onwards , probably accelerated the advent of Federation.

Multi-State aspects of the River Murray waters were alluded to constantly during the great Convention debates which preceded Federation. In these debates, the controversial and contested issues relating to River Murray management were identified.

The first River Murray Waters Agreement, to resolve developing conflicts in the use of River Murray waters, was signed in 1914; legislation came into effect in 1915; and the River Murray Commission was established in 1917. The new Agreement now before this Parliament is the result of the first major review of this important inter-governmental Agreement since those early days. River water quality, particularly in respect of salinity, has now become a key factor in the long-term utilisation of what is regarded by many as the nation's most important water resource. Under the new Agreement, the responsibilities of the River Murray Commission have been extended to include water quality matters, in addition to the responsibilities it has had in the past for water quantity in the main stem of the river and associated storages.

The new Agreement charges the River Murray Commission with the responsibility for monitoring the quality of water in the river, in tributary inflows and in the Commission's storages. To this end, a monitoring network is already well established. The Agreement also authorises the River Murray Commission to formulate water quality objectives or standards for key locations along the river. It is against these objectives or standards that the Commission will have to develop its water management strategies. State authorities are required to inform the Commission of proposals under their consideration which could have a significant effect on water quality or quantity in the river, and to provide the information necessary to enable their likely impact to be assessed. Obviously, the agreed water quality objectives will provide important benchmarks, and the Commission will then make representations, as necessary, to the appropriate State authority on such proposals.

It is also worth noting that the water distribution provisions have been completely recast to ensure, not only an equitable distribution of water between the States, but also allowing each State maximum flexibility in meeting its own particular water demands. Even more importantly, the provisions will enable account to be taken of the quality of tributary inflows and drainage returns to the river from each State in assessing their respective shares of the water resources under the Commission's control. This procedure should provide a strong incentive to each State to improve the quality of flows in its tributaries and from outfalls to the river. In keeping with modern water management principles, the new Agreement now comprehends important river water management objectives for the Commission, additional to its traditional role of supplying water for irrigation. These could also include flood mitigation, environmental protection and recreational uses. For over 65 years, the Commission has operated within the powers defined for it by the four governments. With the enlargement of these powers to encompass water quality, inter-governmental co-operation in the management of the river system now enters a more difficult phase.

As in every river system, water quality is the end product of practically all major activities in the vast catchment of the River Murray-dryland agriculture, irrigation, forestry and urban industrial development. These are all areas of State responsibility, and the realities of the Australian Constitution require that many of the Commission's water quality responsibilities may have to be pursued in consultation and co-operation with the States. While in these areas the Commission will have mainly an advisory role, its powers of persuasion should not be underestimated, particularly if its representations are based on well researched data and are consistent with the overall thrust of the new Agreement. The Government will be maintaining a close interest in the implementation of the new Agreement and, if there are indications that the Agreement needs to be strengthened, we will approach the three States to determine how this might be done.

The Commission retains its autonomy under the new Agreement. This is essential if it is to continue as an effective custodian in the national interest of this most important water resource, and to provide the stimulus for co-operative action by the States in the maintenance and, eventually, improvement of water quality in the River Murray. The Government believes that the new Agreement provides a more adequate framework for inter-governmental co-operation in the development of long term plans for safeguarding the enormous public and private investment in irrigation settlements and urban water supply systems based on the River Murray in the three States. This Agreement, as was the case with its predecessor, depends on the goodwill of the contracting parties for its success. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Address-in-Reply
Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by Ms Fatin:
That the following Address-in-Reply to the Speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY:

We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, desire to express our loyalty to our Most Gracious Sovereign, and to thank Your Excellency for the Speech which you have been pleased to address to Parliament.
