TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Chisholm. I remind honourable members that this is the honourable member's maiden address and ask them to extend the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Mrs H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I offer my congratulations on your election to your very important office. May I, through you, pass on my congratulations to Mr Speaker on his election to his high office. I am very proud, as the first woman and the first Labor member to represent my electorate, to be making my maiden speech in this House before you, Madam Deputy Speaker, one of the first women to occupy the chair, marking the Thirty-third Parliament as the first in which there are women in both Houses serving in positions of authority and responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate that the electorate of Chisholm should have a woman member, as it was named for Caroline Chisholm, who worked so hard and showed such concern for the well-being of women in the early days of European settlement here. It is doubly appropriate for me, as my paternal grandmother was Ellen Chisholm. Her recollections of the joys and trials of her life in the early days of the settlement of the Wimmera region of Victoria enriched my childhood and gave me a deep appreciation of the strength and courage of our pioneer women.

The Box Hill State electorate, which is part of Chisholm, elected a woman member, Mrs Margaret Ray; the Box Hill Council is led by a woman mayor, Councillor Betty Walters; and the Waverley Council, in another part of my electorate, is also led by a woman mayor, Councillor Irene Pederick. In reporting this somewhat unusual situation with some pleasure, it is my hope that by the time Federal Parliament celebrates its centenary, the presence of women in all areas of decision making, government and non-government, will be normal and not exceptional.

In this world, where 'reality' has come to mean something unpleasant and 'ideal ' to mean expensive airy-fairy notion, there is a need for redefinition of those concepts. I believe that good government is the rational implementation of policies centred upon ideals and principles, without which government becomes cynical, expedient and self-seeking. For some years now I have worn a small badge which symbolises an expression of the ideals which I hold central to my political views. In 1949 the then Prime Minister, Mr J. B. Chifley, said:

We do say that it is the duty and responsibility of the community and particularly those more fortunately placed to see that our less fortunate fellow citizens are protected from those shafts of fate which leave them helpless and without hope. This is the objective for which we are striving. It is the beacon, the light on the hill to which our eyes are always turned and to which our efforts are always directed.

That small badge symbolises those words and reminds me constantly of what my responsibilities are. The ideals of a caring compassionate government which would set the goal of national reconciliation, which would set priorities of need rather than greed, which would comprehend the contribution of women in our society to the progress of that society, were overwhelmingly endorsed in March.

It is the responsibility and the duty of every Australian to be aware of the difficulties faced by the less fortunate in our community and the privilege of every Australian to share our good fortune with our fellow citizens upon whom the sun is not shining. The provision of universal health insurance, of adequate education, of legislation against sex discrimination, of better pension systems, of job creation programs, and of community improvement programs are some of the ways in which this Government intends to implement policies informed and illuminated by those ideals held as central by the party to which I belong.

The objective enunciated by Mr Chifley has been a driving force for many people who have worked all their adult lives to have a government which will achieve that objective. It is because of those people that I am here today, and I thank them for their support and their confidence in me. They have worked not for their own benefit but for a government which will give reality to their desire to live in a country which cares for all its inhabitants and in which we can all live in dignity and security.

In my electorate of Chisholm-a pleasant place with tree-lined streets, attractive houses, plentiful parks and sports grounds, a range of industries, a variety of schools and tertiary institutions, a large hospital and many nursing homes and elderly people's villages-there should be every opportunity for its citizens to live that peaceful, secure life which is the right of every Australian. The people of Chisholm believe that it is their right. They believe that it is the business of government to make it possible for all citizens to exercise that right. They are concerned not only for themselves. They are not selfish, uncaring people. They are concerned for those whom they saw to be sadly treated by a government which talked about dole bludgers and social security cheats, which used unemployment as an economic measure, which denied people a sensible health insurance system, which took no action about the vandalism of an area included on the World Heritage List, which encouraged the mining of uranium without any responsibility for its consequences and which allowed poverty to afflict an ever increasing number of its people. They are prepared to share, and they said on 5 March that they cared.

Behind many a front door in my electorate live people now retired, who apparently have everything they need, but in those houses are empty refrigerators, unused heaters, fear and insecurity. The cost of health insurance is the single most burdensome expense borne by those on fixed and ever more inadequate incomes. If they receive pensions they, unlike the tax evaders under the former Government, have every cent of that income scrutinised as if they were criminals instead of their having committed the indiscretion of growing older and retiring from the work force through which they contributed to the well-being of our country. They want and have a right to a government which demonstrates real concern for them and their needs.

In my pleasant electorate over 600 requests for short and long term accommodation were made by homeless young people last year. They too have a right to a caring government which has something better to offer than a future of hopelessness. There are, too, many single parents who look to our Government for support in their difficult task, knowing that real understanding of those difficulties exists in this Government. During the election campaign many people , both men and women, expressed their conviction that there should be more women in parliament, and of course I agreed with them. One of the most exciting events , one which showed how seriously women are interested in political processes, was the meeting attended by over 700 women at which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke ), then the Leader of the Opposition, and Senator Susan Ryan, now Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, announced our Government's policy for women. Women, by their attendance, their questions and their response, made it clear that a very great need exists for positive action to address their needs and concerns. However, the interest in women in Parliament goes back a good while, as I discovered when I was doorknocking. At one house my knock was answered by an elderly lady who said: 'Are you standing for Parliament, my dear?' I said: 'Yes, I am'. She inquired what party I was representing, and I told her the Australian Labor Party. She said: 'Well, I believe that is a very respectable party, my dear'. Then she said that she would vote for me because she had waited 84 years to vote for a woman. That is a long wait. I am glad she got what she wanted.

Women everywhere are showing their concern for good government in a whole range of issues. They are speaking out about the social structure of this country, about the future of children and young people, about the dangers of nuclear power and nuclear weapons, about the health and security of its people. They want peace, stability, consensus and equity. It says something to the women of this country about the nature of political parties here that all the women in this House are on this side.

One of the characteristics of many people in my electorate is a deep and abiding love of the landscape. I share that love of our beautiful and unique country, so I share with them their passionate concern about the vandalism taking place and planned in South West Tasmania. The wilderness in Tasmania is also in Australia and therefore the concern of all Australians. The heritage area is the responsibility of all Australians to preserve for the future generations of peoples of the world. I have listened to arguments which seem based on the claim that Tasmania is virtually a foreign land in which only Tasmanians have any rights and for which only Tasmanians of this generation have any responsibility. I reject those arguments.

In the 200 years of our occupation of this continent we have already, in ignorance and selfishness, caused destruction which we now regret but cannot repair. We have levelled mountains, drowned valleys, choked rivers, created deserts and caused many species of animals and plants to become extinct. I remind honourable members that 18 species of animals and plants became extinct when Lake Pedder was enlarged. We know better and we should do better. The world heritage area is just that-an area which we hold in trust for the world. No claim of other rights and no secret activities of destruction can deny the Australian Government's responsibility to preserve that area. I am glad that we have accepted that responsibility. All of us must regard our heritage with much deeper understanding of the value of the land and its natural life as a vital part of our social structure. We live on and with the land. That does not mean either the broad acres to which some fortunate people hold title, nor the mortgaged suburban block, but the land as a whole which belongs to all citizens and is held in trust by governments and private owners for our future citizens. We have, in this country, no pyramids and palaces to put us in touch with our past. But we do have our land which is our past and our future. We have much to learn from our original Australians about the value of the land for our spiritual and psychological health.

Before I came to the Parliament I spent many years in the field of education. During that time, the whole nature of education changed or should have changed. What has not changed are the gross inequities in educational opportunity which still exist. The previous Labor Government made great advances in lifting education out of its nineteenth century doldrums, especially in funding a much wider range of tertiary institutions, making tertiary education available to many more people than had previously been the case and thereby lifting the level of skill and understanding in our country. The first steps were taken towards the principle of giving all those involved in schools some decision-making power . Autonomy was granted to tertiary institutions so that they were able to provide courses which met the needs of the communities they served. However, rapid changes in our society need rapid responses from the education system. This is not yet happening. An elitist view of education emphasises tradition and achievement in traditional skills. This view which has predominated recently holds back the process of educational change.

Schools need to serve the whole population and therefore the great differences in resources provide our society with an ever-increasing number of young adults who have been disadvantaged by their time in school rather than prepared for adult life. That schools, in their resources and their abilities to cope with changing needs, still reflect the resources and average income levels of the communities in which they exist, makes a mockery of the notion of equality of educational opportunity.

Young people today face a world of complexity and insecurity. Unemployment, the arms race, disappearing professions and the demands of the peer group together make young people take decisions about their future with no conviction that those decisions are meaningful. Teaching strategies may ignore the technological competence of young people because their teachers neither have, nor have the opportunity to gain, a similar technological competence. The computers in schools program is a first step towards providing the education system with a line to the real world. If we are to have an education system to meet the needs of our community we have to be prepared to discard many of our notions about the good old days and start moving towards an understanding of the changes our society has already experienced and will be experiencing in the future. The Curriculum Development Centre has a vital role to play in assisting education to meet change. For too long the education system has been without that vital resource.

In this week during which International Women's Day for Disarmament was commemorated, I draw attention to the range of initiatives this Government is planning to implement on this vitally important issue. The human race, after nuclear war, will not be divided into the quick and the dead but into the dead and the dying. This country must, as every country must, do everything in its power to help the world draw back from the perilous position in which we all stand. We do not want to bring up our children in a world on the brink of destruction. We do not want to bring up our children in a world suffering tension and stress from the imminent threat of destruction. The courage shown by our children in facing up to the uncertainties of the employment situation, of technological change and of the rapid changes taking place in our society should be recognised. How better to recognise that courage than by the Government of their country taking positive and sensible steps towards giving their world a safer future?

I have spoken about rights and responsibility, about duty and privilege, about ideal and reality. It might be said that those large words do not put bread in the cupboard and blankets on the bed. However, unless a government is mindful of its duties and responsibilities, its ideals and the rights of its citizens, it will not take the proper action to ensure the bread in the cupboard and the blankets on the bed. Unless a government is just as conscious of the needs of its poorest citizens as it is of the wants of its richest, it will not be a government for the people; it will only be a government for some of the people. Unless, as a government, we have our beacon, our light on the hill, we will not succeed, because success for us is not just staying in power as a political party. Success for us is developing a better world for our citizens to live in. It can mean as little as changing a form to take the hassle out of getting some medicine and as much as removing fear and insecurity from the lives of our citizens. Government to us is a greater challenge because we have a greater objective.

I am both proud and conscious of the responsibility that I have to accept that challenge for the people of the electorate of Chisholm. I wish to thank the people who have supported and inspired me over the years, my campaign committee, the branch members and the many Labor Party supporters. I wish to pay tribute to my family-my husband, son and mother-in-law. Without their support and loving care my job would be much more difficult. I wish to thank the members of both State and Federal parliamentary parties for their generous assistance and advice and the members from both sides of this House for their courteous and warm welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I wish to join with others in congratulating you upon your elevation to your office. I would be grateful if you would convey to Mr Speaker my congratulations on his election, unopposed, to the important office of Speaker. The Speaker, the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins), has, I think, earned the admiration and respect of people on both sides of the House. He has proved himself to be a man of great sincerity and impartiality. Already he has guided this House with some distinction. I also wish to congratulate the honourable member for Chisholm (Ms Mayer) on her maiden speech which was a very thoughtful contribution. I too share her view that in the future we should see more women elected to both sides of this Parliament to make the contributions which they are capable of making to constructive debate in this Parliament. I want to congratulate all those new honourable members who have taken their place in this Parliament. Particularly I wish to congratulate my new National Party of Australia colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) on his election to this Parliament and for the quality of his maiden speech. I wish him a very long and outstanding career in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In spite of the cynicisms of some people about this great parliamentary institution, cynicisms that we probably earn by our conduct and behaviour, this is the most important democratically elected institution in this country. All of us should be mindful of the great honour and trust that is imposed upon the elected representatives of this Parliament by the Australian people to serve their interests. No summit, round table conference or other forums can or should be allowed to take the place of this treasured inheritance. The National Economic Summit Conference which was conducted in this chamber five weeks ago provided a valuable forum for an exchange of ideas, but it could have been held in the Albert Hall or, for that matter, in the Gulargambone grain shed. Although the non-parliamentary participants represented some interest groups, concepts and philosophies, they were not the representatives of the wider views of the Australian people.

The Summit provided a forum, an opportunity for an exchange of views, an exchange of ideas and a way in which people could get together, discuss their attitudes and try to understand the attitudes of others. Of course, the Government took the opportunity to place its economic facts on the table. It also provided the newly-elected Government with an excuse to retreat from a number of its election promises that it had no intention of fulfilling, such as an immediate reduction in taxes for six million Australians, no tax increases for farmers, a 3c a litre reduction in fuel prices, tax concessions for small businesses, half a million new jobs to be created and the Alice Springs-Darwin railway to be completed by 1988. It was an opportunity to issue a communique that purported to reflect a resolution by all parties to support a plan for consensus, rehabilitation and reconciliation. During the Summit, the Government promised the Australian Council for Trade Unions that it would not introduce further taxation on lump sum superannuation payments. Of course, this promise has been broken already. Although the communique was supported by all parliamentarians, except the redoubtable and far-seeing Premier of Queensland and the inspired Tasmanian Premier, a close reading of the document reveals that no explicit agreement was reached on critically important specifics in regard to the wage pause. Since the Summit the ACTU has made a mockery of the so-called Summit consensus. Where is the consensus today?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is none.

—As the Leader of the National Party of Australia says, there is none. Within a month we have even seen the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) publicly admonish the ACTU because of its application to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission initially for a 9 per cent increase this year and a provision for catch-up of real wages forgone since the pause. Mr Simon Crean, since Cliff Dolan's departure overseas, has come out with another formula. There is no doubt that members of the ACTU are completely and utterly confused. They have no intention of honouring the spirit of consensus, reconciliation and reconstruction. Unfortunately, the Australian Labor Party's pre-election rhetoric was not conducive to giving the leadership that was necessary to the Labor movement and to the union movement during that election campaign. The Labor Party rejected the former Government's appeal for wage moderation and a wage pause for 12 months. They fought the election campaign upon it. They fought the election campaign with an alternative approach for a Summit Conference but with no details spelt out as to what that Summit Conference was intended to achieve. Of course, their rhetoric has undoubtedly confused and not given the leadership that the union movement badly needs at this time.
—The country needs it too.

—The country needs it, indeed. In any event the agreed communique from the Summit failed to address the real issues in specific terms such as the duration of the wage pause and the need to forgo catch-up. I was astonished that so many people, who should have known better, fell for that communique which was in many ways a meaningless document. The communique merely accepted that future wage increases were a matter for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and that, while the maintenance of real wages is a key to the objectives of the union movement, in a period of economic crisis it will be an objective over time . That was a vague, and a deliberately vague, definition of timing. This vagueness, which is a feature of the communique, has left its legacy of wide interpretation and misrepresentation.
—It will be an historic document.

—The honourable member for Hunter has said that it will be an historic document. He is quite right. It will be an infamous document. It will be a document upon which this Government will ultimately perish. Since the Summit, the Prime Minister has indicated that the nation could withstand full indexation in 1984 if wages were increased by only 3 per cent to 4 per cent towards the end of this year. Even a drover's dog would agree that if there is to be any hope of real recovery in the economy, profits need to be increased before there are any real increases in wages. Increased job opportunities will return only with increased profit margins.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Economic Summit Conference was an imaginative concept but the Government failed at the end of the day to persuade the unions to accept the need for a wage pause for the rest of this year. The communique was a vague compromise embodying a soft option. Clearly, the parties to the communique should have accepted the need for a wages pause for 12 months and the need to forgo a catch-up at the end of the pause, leaving the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with the big responsibility of determining the capacity of the economy to pay and the quantum of the increase in 1984. A 12-months wage pause is especially necessary to enable our vital export industries to recover their competitive trading positions. I refer to our great agricultural, mining and pastoral industries.

I represent one of the great agricultural and pastoral electorates in Australia , in which there is also a significant amount of mining. I therefore wish to say something about the importance of these industries in general and the rural industries in particular. People living in the towns and on the farms in my electorate-indeed, throughout most of rural Australia-are financially, physically and emotionally exhausted after years of drought, low commodity prices, high costs and the unemployment due to those factors. Successive droughts in eastern Australia have had a disastrous effect on the rural sector of our economy. The recent drought, one of the worst this century, has been a major contributor to the current recession. Direct revenue losses to farmers in this year will amount to about $2,500m. When the multiplier effect is taken into account, that will amount to a loss to the community of about $5,000m.

The Australian economy remains heavily dependent upon agriculture. The rural sector, though a minority grouping, is of fundamental importance to the standard of living of all Australians. It is a vital element in the economy. This is why the people in country areas were dismayed at the way in which the mini-Budget discriminated against them. About 30 per cent of the cuts in the mini-Budget for 1983-84 will be met by people living in rural Australia. Let me spell out the rural share of these cuts. The decision not to proceed with the Bicentennial Water Resources Program has shot Split Rock Dam to death. The dam that was necessary to give security to people in the Namoi Valley, to the cotton growers, to the small business people and to the whole of that valley, is shot to bits. That was to cost $70m.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Burdekin Dam?
—The Burdekin Dam was in doubt and the Government has not clarified the position.
—It would be tragic if that were stopped.

—It would be absolutely tragic. If the Government wants job creation schemes, why does it not go for something that will improve the national asset at the same time as creating jobs? Changes to the fuel freight subsidy scheme amount to $10m and changes to the tax averaging provisions for farmers involve $ 15m. The extension from three to five years for the depreciation of certain plant and equipment for farmers will cost them a further $9m.
—They hate the country.

—Yes. The removal of the interest rate subsidy for the Australian Wheat Board totals $19.8m. Sure, the Board now has the flexibility to borrow overseas that we were planning for it, but the subsidy provision has been taken away. The deferral of elements of the aerodrome local ownership plan will cost the rural community another $8m. This gives a total of $131.8m. In spite of what the Treasurer (Mr Keating) had to say the other day, that represents 30 per cent of the total savings of $427m. Of course the percentage would be higher if one added the share of the cost of postal and telecommunications charge rises that will occur as a result of Telecom Australia losing the subsidy arrangements on its borrowings. We should also bear in mind the increased cost of aviation fuel, the virtual abandonment of the Alice Springs-Darwin railway line and other changes to tax expenditures and concessions. Therefore, about 7 per cent of the Australian population will have to meet about 30 per cent of the cost of the mini-Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The farmers, middle income earners, small businessmen and women and the self- employed are the main contributors to the boost to housing, job creation schemes and the costly Medicare program. How stupid could this Government be to try to bring back that wretched Medibank thing at a time when the economy is in a sorry , sick state and confusing everybody once again? It is significant that the great corporations have largely escaped. These groups were heavily represented at the National Economic Summit Conference. I believe that the Prime Minister has now put himself in a position where he is the man who will preside over the conferences of the large union leaders and the great corporations.

It is also significant that the unsung heroes of this nation-the farmers, the middle income earners, the small businessmen and women and the self-employed- were represented by only two members at the Summit. Indeed, the hardest working people-the backbone of Australia-have been slugged by this Government. Small investors will lose from the abolition of the dividend taxation concession. Thousands of families will lose from the elimination of the housing interest rebate scheme. Small-time superannuants will lose through the 30 per cent tax on lump sum payments. Farmers, after years of drought, self-denial and restraint will be the heaviest losers. This is a sad indictment of a government-a Labor government-that offered the little Australians promise, hope, reconciliation and rehabilitation.

The Government has engaged in a deceptive, discriminatory exercise against those who were least represented at the National Economic Summit Conference. So, today, instead of the promised immediate tax cuts for six million Australians, we find that the average family will be $8 a week worse off. We are told that there is more to come in the August Budget, including the one per cent levy for this incredible return of Medibank. I believe that most Australians will accept necessary reductions in Budget outlays as long as they are fair and do not discriminate against sections of the community. Let us hope that the rural industries are not going to be singled out again. They have the potential of making a 3 per cent increase to gross domestic product, which would be an enormous contribution to Australia's economic recovery if the Hawke Government were prepared to give them a fair go.

Rural industries account for nearly 50 per cent of Australia's export earnings. Although the drought has broken in most areas, the cash drought remains in farming industries. The removal of tax concessions and other forms of assistance to industries will not help rural industries to recover and contribute to a general economic recovery. The National Farmers Federation submission to the National Economic Summit Conference presented the case so clearly and comprehensively. I hope that every member of the Government reads and absorbs it . This submission made the point that 70 per cent or 78,000 of broadacre farms in Australia will not earn sufficient income to pay for normal living expenses and to service the debt in 1982-83. Sixty per cent of farmers will earn incomes of less than the unemployment benefit for a married man and two children of $149 per week. Indeed, the level of farm income per man-year of family labour will on average drop from about $11,000 in 1981-82 to about $2,100 in 1982-83.

TALK.START.PARA: —How far below the poverty line is that?

—It is well below the poverty line. Who talks about poverty in the rural sector? Very few are prepared to acknowledge the great poverty that is occurring in rural areas. Therefore, 11 per cent of farmers in Australia are at risk due to factors outside and beyond their control. There is an urgent need for the provision of substantially increased rural adjustment assistance. I would have thought that the mini-Budget would have made immediate provisions for additional funds for adjustment assistance. The former Government made a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission on this issue and the Commission's report should be in the hands of the Government right now.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Government supporters do not like to hear the truth. I assume that the report recommends additional funds for rural adjustment. The Government must respond generously to that need. Whilst there is a need for additional funds for rural adjustment, it would be crazy constantly to rely upon rural adjustment funds to bail out the rural industries. That section of the community should not be the only one that has to face adjustment and reconstruction.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the economic problems of the rural industries are a direct result of the high cost of protection given the secondary industries. Rural export industries have had constantly to increase their productivity and efficiency in order to survive in a highly competitive overseas market. That rule has not been applied to many of those highly protected secondary industries which have in many cases been the pacesetters for higher wages and better conditions. Time and again we have seen governments avoid the great issue of the need to reduce the level of protection in this country. The farming community, in particular, is expected to become more and more efficient. The time has come for this country to accept the need for reconstruction in so of many of its industries. I hope that the Government will not fall for the suggestion that it give additional tariff protection to the steel industry. I hope that it will face up to its responsibility and ensure that that secondary industry becomes as efficient as rural industries.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Debate (on motion by Mr Saunderson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement
Debate resumed from 25 May, on the following paper presented by Mr Beazley:
Aircraft Accident-Report and Ministerial Statement, 25 May 1983.
and on motion by Mr West:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement made yesterday by the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) was a thoroughly responsible approach to the report made by the Board of Accident Inquiry into the disaster which, on 21 February 1980, at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, cost 13 lives. The Board's work was itself commendable. The report is detailed, thorough and fair. The Board was not able to come to a firm view as to the precise reasons for the accident but listed, in summarising its conclusions after making a painstaking examination of the evidence, various factors which contributed to the accident. I wish to make one or two comments arising out of the Board's report and, if I depart from what the Minister has said, he will understand that I am approaching the report in the same vein as that in which he has approached it.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I go to finding No. 1, which appears at page 274 of the report. This is one of the findings summarised under the heading 'Causes of the Accident'. The Board stated:
There are a number of factors which in combination were contributing causes of the accident. On the balance of probabilities, the Board considers they are as follows:
1. The aircraft was in excess of its maximum permissible take-off weight by some 110 to 150 kg, which in the circumstances would have had a minor detrimental effect on its climb performance.
The operator and the pilot were each partly responsible for the understatement of weight.
It appears from page 246 of the report that officers of the Department of Transport were aware of what might be called a practice. The report states:

It is clear that some officers of the Department of Transport were aware that the maintenance being carried out by the operator was unsatisfactory in certain respects. At least one officer was also aware that non-standard weights for passengers were being used for the calculation of aircraft loads and that less than full power was being applied on some take-offs. Accordingly, the question is raised, so far as is relevant to the accident, of the adequacy of the departmental surveillance which was carried out.

The Board came to the conclusion that it was advisable to have what it called ' surprise checks' and it proposed the institution of a system of such checks within a few months of any particularly critical surveillance report to ensure that corrective action had been taken. The Minister, at page 10 of his statement , considered that proposal but rejected it. I would ask the Minister to have another look at that recommendation of the Board. I do not suggest that the Board's recommendation necessarily has to be adopted in precisely the terms put by the Board, but I do suggest that it might be looked at somewhat along the lines of a random audit within a large company, which has two benefits. First, the audit, when carried out, can disclose factors which would need correction. Secondly, the existence of a system of random audits in itself would instil a certain measure of fear into those who might otherwise cut corners when it comes to maintenance.

I refer now to the power setting of the aircraft at the time of take off. In paragraph 24 of the chapter entitled 'Summary of Principal Conclusions, Observations and Causes of the Accident', on page 269 of the report, it is stated:

The evidence supports the conclusion, however, that power was set at a lower figure of 700*C ITT, following a provision introduced by the operator into the Operations Manual. This provision was an unsafe guide and contrary to the Air Navigation Regulations.

I emphasise the words 'unsafe guide'. This conclusion is picked up later in finding 5 of the Board's report, at page 274, where it is said that the setting of the power at that lower level would have seriously curtailed engine output. This practice was apparently known to the Department as something which occurs or might occur from time to time. In relation to the use of reduced power, on page 272 it is stated:
Senior officers of the Department were aware of rumours of the practice, but took no action to alert Examiners of Airmen to the risks involved or the need to put a stop to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12 noon, the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101 (a). The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
—Mr Speaker, I take this opportunity of informing the House that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) has been appointed Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I remind the Prime Minister of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs earlier this week in which he said, in relation to the very complicated and sensitive question of trying to resolve the problems of Cambodia, that at this stage he ruled out nothing and included nothing. Does the Prime Minister approve of acting Ministers making statements on policy issues which have not been discussed with either the Government or the responsible Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for Corangamite for his very genuine interest in this matter and in the events of earlier in the week. He, like all honourable members, will remember the brilliant response of my Foreign Minister. It will remain in our memories for some time. The situation is quite clear. I agree absolutely with what the Foreign Minister said-that nothing will be excluded. The Foreign Minister, in the short time that he has occupied that portfolio, has established the position of this Government in regard to our international relationships generally, and in regard to the Indo-China area in particular, as being based upon a sound comprehension of the relevancies in this area. Already, in his visits to countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, in his discussions in Europe and in his communications with other interested parties, as well as in our discussions with Premier Zhao of China, he and the Government have established not merely our bona fides but the opportunity for this country to play a significant role in trying to bring peace to that tragic country of Kampuchea.

ANSWER.PARA: I turn to that part of the question which asks whether I approve of acting Ministers making statements in their area without first consulting. When a Minister assumes the position of acting Minister-by definition, he will not be able to consult with a Minister who is overseas-I have no objection to an acting Minister expressing a point of view if the expression of that point of view does nothing to inhibit the proper conduct of the affairs of this Government in regard to that portfolio. My judgment is that the great initiatives that have already been taken by my Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, will in no way be inhibited by any statements that were made by the acting Minister in his absence .

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Will the Government allow its decisions on the taxation of lump sum superannuation payments to be influenced by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots, which is reported to be planning a totally unjustified ban on flights in and out of Canbera in protest at the Government's position?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for her question. The immediate answer is no, we will not. But I think it is appropriate that all honourable members have the opportunity of understanding this Government's position on this matter. In respect of the particular organisation concerned, that of the airline pilots-I shall have a bit more to say about it-I suggest that it would be appropriate that it should conduct itself like the umbrella organisation of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, to which it is not affiliated, and in respect of that organisation there has been an admirable course of conduct. Discussions have been held between the Treasurer and the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty, in the absence overseas of Mr Dolan. As a result of those amicable discussions a meeting will be held in Sydney tomorrow at 2 o'clock between the Treasurer and representatives of the ACTU. There is no threat of industrial action on the part of the ACTU. It has concerns but it has said: 'We would like to talk about the matter'. Sensibly, rationally and in a civilised fashion that is what is going to happen.

ANSWER.PARA: I suggest it would be appropriate if the airline pilots organisation could learn to conduct itself in a similar fashion. Instead of threatening to impose action which will affect all members of this House and all other people who are wanting to commute to Canberra by air, it should request to meet with the Treasurer. I take this opportunity of saying to the airline pilots-who I believe are to meet, or may be meeting at this moment-that if they seek to have discussions with the Treasurer, he will meet with them, just as he will meet with the ACTU tomorrow. But he will not meet with them if they are in the process of taking industrial action. That is an unqualified position of this Government.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand from the noises that are coming from honourable members opposite that that is a position which is not accepted by them. The airline pilots organisation should understand, as indeed should all citizens of Australia, what the Government is about in this matter. The airline pilots are talking from a position of very considerable privilege. Since 1 July 1980 pilots of Ansett Airlines of Australia have received an increase in salary of 42.7 per cent, and pilots of Trans Australia Airlines have received an increase of 38.8 per cent. In other words, we are talking about a group of people who, since 1 July 1980, have received an increase in their salaries of around 40 per cent, for working a 74-hour month. These are the people who in the context of the actions of this Government have taken this action. Our job creation programs have been designed to assist the young men and women of this country in the 15- year-old to 19-year-old age group. One in three of these young people is without a job. Our programs, including what we have done in regard to superannuation, have been calculated to put this Government in a financial position in which it can undertake programs which will create jobs for people, including the one in three young people who cannot get jobs.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government regards it as somewhat offensive, in a situation in which we are asking the community, including those best placed, to make some sacrifice, that perhaps the most privileged group in this country in terms of remuneration per hour worked should refuse to bear some burden and threaten the rest of the community because it is asked to play some part in this process which will help us to put young people to work. I make it clear that if the airline pilots adopt the program of threatening to take industrial action and take industrial action we will not in those circumstances talk to them. But if they will behave, like the rest of the organised trade union movement, and say 'We wish to talk with you' then we are prepared to listen to them. It is quite possible that they may have some concerns which are worthy of discussion. This Government stands ready to meet with them if they will conduct themselves in a manner appropriate to the peculiarly privileged position which they have in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Treasurer. I refer him to the answer he gave yesterday in which he indicated that revised official forecasts about growth next financial year were not yet available to him and, in fact, might not be available until close to the Budget. Is it a fact that last Thursday night at a Press briefing conducted by Dr Barry Hughes of his private office and Mr Ross Garnaut of the Prime Minister's private office, those attending were informed that revised gross domestic product forecasts available to the Government indicated a growth outcome in 1983-84 of approximately 4.1 per cent? If so, why did the Treasurer mislead the House yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not mislead the House at all. Yesterday the former Treasurer asked me about the growth forecasts of the Department of the Treasury. I indicated to him that the Treasury Department was just beginning its next forecasting round and that the likelihood was that those figures would be ready for the Government well ahead of the Budget. I also indicated that it was never the former Treasurer's practice to publish or to give information on growth forecasts on a regular basis. The only growth forecast that we ever received from the former Treasurer was in the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as Dr Barry Hughes and Mr Ross Garnaut are concerned, apparently some journalists expressed the wish to have a background briefing on certain areas of the Government's statement made last week. Dr Hughes and Mr Garnaut were made available to explain certain areas of the statement which I had introduced that night that were under query. I am not aware of any precise estimates or forecasts which either gentleman gave to members of the Press. But I indicate to the honourable member that I know there were discussions on what one may term an 'on the back of an envelope' basis about what changes, if any, had taken place in, if you like, the inflation growth forecasts and the illustrative scenario I put to the National Economic Summit Conference. Since that time there have been extensive drought-breaking rains. There would be every expectation that next year farm sector growth will be far higher than projected at the time scenario A was put together. I think both Mr Garnaut and Dr Hughes were alluding to that fact, that the likelihood was that, as far as farm GDP is concerned-I do not think any precision can be brought to estimates for non-farm GDP-there is every likelihood that the farm sector will grow further. One has only to look out the window to see that.

The point of the former Treasurer's question was that the $9.6 billion deficit, the fiscal inheritance which was left to this Government by the irresponsible fiscal recklessness of the former Government, was, in some way, only a sort of stab in the dark figure which would be wound back by growth. At the time the Government was presented with that figure the prospects for growth in 1983-84 were, in actuality, far less than they are now, given the fact that the farm sector is likely to be a lot stronger. It was worked out on the basis of 1.5 per cent of GDP, as the former Treasurer well knows. I told him that. I indicated in scenario A that the increase we were looking at was 2.7 per cent. I further indicate that since the drought-breaking rains there may be further growth. I have no information to give the honourable gentleman today, any more than I had yesterday, about precise forecasts coming from the forecasting round by the Treasury.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister in his capacity as temporary Leader of the House. Has his attention been drawn to the speech during the adjournment debate on Tuesday night by the honourable member for Melbourne alleging the secret involvement of the now Leader of the Opposition with the previous Soviet Ambassador and other Soviet apparatchiks as late as January 1983? In view of the fact that the Leader of the Opposition has now been briefed by the Prime Minister and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation on material which appears at least potentially related to the question of agents of influence, and that this is the last day of sitting, will the Minister arrange for the Leader of the Opposition to have the fullest opportunity to explain to this House his relationship with the Soviet Embassy and its agents to prevent the necessity of his being called before the Hope Royal Commission?

—Yes, I did note what was said in the speech on the adjournment by the honourable member for Melbourne the other evening. I noticed particularly that apart from the Soviet personnel who were nominated other people were also nominated. It is a matter of significance, particularly in view of recent allegations. The Leader of the Opposition might well want to make an explanation that he did not have access to any intelligence. On that basis we would be very happy for him to make a statement at any time after Question Time.

—My question, which is directed to the Treasurer, arises out of attachment B to the economic statement. Does the Treasurer recall saying that if lump sums received by the executor or the dependants of a deceased person represent amounts from superannuation funds they will be treated within the new arrangement, as though they had been received by that person while living? Drawing the distinction between a benefit paid to a living person and a benefit paid to a deceased, does this mean the Government is now involved in a policy of death duties?

—The principle which the Government articulated in the statement last week holds up in all cases. Yesterday a similar question was asked by the honourable member for Mitchell in respect of a widow. If a widow were to receive from an estate a lump sum that lump sum would be taxed at the rate of 30 per cent. If, however, that was invested in an annuity it would be exempt from tax. I have indicated also that the Government will look at making the income from annuities very much more attractive than it would otherwise be. That was the purpose of the superannuation scheme in the first place.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to a report that the French Government has exploded a nuclear device on Mururoa Atoll? If so, can he indicate the Government's attitude to this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the long standing concern that the honourable member for Fadden has had on the issue of arms control and disarmament and his oft expressed concern about the dangers of an untrammelled nuclear arms race. In that respect I appreciate his question. I received advice literally in the last five minutes that the French have exploded, according to initial reports, a 70 kiloton nuclear device at Mururoa Atoll. That makes it a large device if the reports are correct-it is much larger than a trigger device which is what the French authorities declared to me they were restricting themselves to testing at Mururoa Atoll when I was in France a few weeks ago. What it makes abundantly clear is justification for greater emphasis which the Opposition is devoting to the issue of arms control and disarmament and especially to the nuclear arms race. I anticipate bipartisan concern and support on this issue. I recall that my two predecessors frequently voiced protests on this matter. In Paris recently I expressed the strongest protest to the French Foreign Minister, Monsieur Cheysson, about French testing in the South West Pacific. I have to say for the record that he, equally as strongly, rejected my protest and made it clear that France will continue testing in the South West Pacific. In that regard the concern of the Government to raise at the forthcoming South Pacific Forum meeting in Canberra the possibility of a nuclear-free South West Pacific, as a first step in what would be a very long journey towards a nuclear-free South Pacific, is well and truly justified. It is a matter that I signalled to Mr Namaliu, the Foreign Minister of Papua New Guinea, who will take the matter back to his Government for discussion.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has indicated to me that the testing of nuclear weaponry by the French in the South West Pacific is also a matter which he will take up with the French when he is there in a little over a week's time. He will put quite firmly Australia's concern about the use of the South West Pacific as a nuclear testing ground by the French, or indeed by any other power. I express our concern about this. I am registering a strong protest. That protest will be going to the French authorities. I acknowledge that protests in the past have not discouraged the French authorities, nor has the International Court of Justice. Accordingly I re-emphasise my determination to push ahead as quickly but as sensibly as I can to achieve some sort of concept of a nuclear-free South West Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Health. I refer to the Minister's rejection of the proposal of the private health insurance funds to handle Medicare on an agency basis and his decision to centralise all basic insurance under Medibank. Is it a fact that he is spending $80m of taxpayers' money in this time of high unemployment to create a net loss of at least 2,000 jobs in this industry? Does this not represent a job destruction cost of $40,000 per job ? Is this part of the Government's program of national consensus, recovery and reconstruction?

—As I have pointed out on previous occasions, in making this decision, which as I have said was a difficult one, we had to look at the long term interests in the health field, which certainly were not addressed by the previous Government in changing scheme after scheme. In making the decision to spend somewhat greater in the short term, we believed we were justified on the grounds of producing a system which, firstly, would be much more cost efficient for some of the reasons implicit in the question asked by the honourable member for Mackellar. Secondly, it would provide a central monitoring system far more effective in reviewing and dealing with fraud and overservicing. As the honourable member suggested, while overall jobs are endangered in the field, there will be an expansion of job opportunities in Medicare and we are giving preference to people from the private funds for those jobs. Also, as the Minister for Health in New South Wales indicated yesterday, his Government will give support in giving preference for jobs within the Department of Health to people from the private funds. Finally, as I have pointed out time and again, despite the misinformation that is being circulated, the turnover rate of jobs- that is, the wastage rate-is quite high in the private funds. Therefore, if the funds are prepared to co-operate with the Government, coupled with some future steps that will be taken in relation to private health insurance, I believe no individual redundancies should occur.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. It concerns the Government' s decision to support a return to a centralised system of wage fixation at the next national wage case. What are the essential conditions required for the success of a centralised wages system? Can the Australian community as a whole make any contribution to ensure that the new wages system will be a success?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Eden-Monaro for his question. On a number of occasions in the last few weeks I have outlined to the House the commitment of this Government to a wages policy which is coherent, understandable, workable and equitable. I repeat that the essential ingredient of that policy, which is quite clear on our part, is that there be a suppression of wage claims outside the national wage case hearings except in the most exceptional circumstances. In regard to that part of the honourable member's question as to what would be the best conditions for the operation of such a policy in this country, I have to say-I think most honourable members would agree-that a precondition for having this system work most efficiently is a degree of bipartisan support for such a policy. However, as we look at the Press over recent days we lose all hope of reaching a position of such bipartisan support. The other day the Minister for Foreign Affairs referred rather tellingly to the meanderings of the Leader of the Opposition in his previous capacity as Minister for Foreign Affairs-meanderings particularly, as I recall, between Los Angeles and New York. Here on the domestic front there is certainly a lot of meandering going on as far as the Leader of the Opposition is concerned on this question of wages policy. I refer to the Canberra Times of 24 May, which contains a report of a fascinating interview that the Leader of the Opposition had with one Colin Brammall. Mr Peacock stated:

ANSWER.PARA: But in the meantime we are doing a full reappraisal of our wages policy.
Mr Peacock went on, in his lovely, colloquial, direct way of talking with people :

But, mate . . . I just don't regard criticism that 'Ah, well you haven't got a policy in this area' as meaning anything other than, you know, a short-term criticism because if we were to re-enunciate last year's stuff we'd be going backwards.

Indeed, they would. Our understanding of the possibility of getting this bipartisan basis of support for a wages policy is made clearer by the references in this morning's Press. The Sydney Morning Herald states:
The Opposition spokesman on employment, Mr Macphee, has launched a major criticism of the wages policy of the shadow Treasurer, Mr Howard . . .
It goes on:
The split within the Liberal Party over wages policy has deepened since Mr Macphee circulated a five-page paper to his shadow ministry colleagues . . .
The article further states:
Mr Macphee says the Fraser Government move towards a decentralised system had devastating economic consequences . . .
A similar report in the Canberra Times today states:
The issue is potentially so divisive that the Opposition front bench is believed to have agreed to avoid making public statements on it until an ' official' position is reached.

In those circumstances one can see the total inability of any reasonable person to take seriously the Opposition's protestations in the area of wage policy when its critically important shadow Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations says that the policy of the shadow Treasurer, which had been pursued, was economically disastrous for this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. He had better listen to it; I have a real telex here. In the light of reports that independent petroleum agents and contractors will not be permitted to pick up product from oil company terminals after 22 May 1983 and that product is to be delivered only by Transport Workers Union oil industry drivers, with the threat of industrial action by the Federated Storemen and Packers Union and the Transport Workers Union, will the Minister advise us of his attitude to the Laidely agreement which seeks to maintain fair opportunities for independent petrol distributors, agents and retailers? Is he aware of a definite threatened national TWU campaign for the wage rise promised by the union from 1 January 1983-yet another indication that the 3 to 4 per cent increase in wages this year--
—Order! I do not want to stop the honourable member but he is putting far too much information in his question.
—It is very important, Mr Speaker. This telex tells everything. We are talking about a coherent wages policy.

—Order! The honourable member for Franklin will resume his seat. May I point out to the honourable member that, while the matter he is raising might be very important, it is outside the Standing Orders which this House gives me to supervise. I invite him to bring his question to its point.

—Mr Speaker, I apologise to you. I think you are a real gentleman. Is this yet another indication that the 3 to 4 per cent increase in wages this year foreshadowed by the Government is unrealistic and if the TWU does not get what it wants we will have a strike?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the histrionic or hysterical honourable member for Franklin, let me say that there is no possibility of the wages system in this country in the second half of this year resulting in a greater increase than the 3 or 4 per cent that the Government has said is its policy in respect of wage increases in that time. We have-as the Prime Minister, I, the Treasurer and other spokesmen have said many times in the course of the last month-adopted a policy which will ensure that we have a centralised system of wage fixation operating in this country and that that system will result in an increase in wages of no more than 4 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to transport workers, I think it was only last week that the Transport Workers Union federal conference was held in Canberra. At that conference the transport workers made it clear that they fully supported the move to a centralised wages system and that they would accept the national wage increase in terms of wage increases for transport workers in the rest of this year. So at that top level of the Transport Workers Union there has quite recently been a full acceptance of the Government's policy in that area.

I am not aware of the specific elements in respect of independent contractors that the honourable member mentioned in his question. I am aware, however, that this is an important area of controversy in the transport industry. It is a matter which has been discussed at the National Labour Consultative Council. It will come up for discussion again later on. I will certainly pay close attention to developments in that area. I hope we can come to a satisfactory resolution of this long-standing problem in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Primary Industry agree that with cattle numbers in Australia at an all time low it would be an opportune time to accelerate the tuberculosis and brucellosis eradication campaign? Does the Minister accept that a potential threat to our markets exists if Australia does not eradicate these diseases? Does the Minister acknowledge that there can be no hope of eradicating tuberculosis unless the feral buffalo herd, principally in the Northern Territory, is destroyed? Does he recognise that disease in northern cattle poses a threat to all cattle in Australia and control cannot therefore be left entirely to the caprices of the extravagant and irresponsible Northern Territory Government?

—Order! Before calling the Minister to answer, I think I should just remind honourable members on both sides of the House to observe please in asking questions that only that information which is necessary to have the question properly answered is included.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I thank you for your advice in respect of the last part of the question. I would have been delighted to respond. The honourable member for the Northern Territory and the honourable member for Leichhardt have also raised this question with me in recent days and weeks. A lot of information on this matter is publicly available. There have been two Industries Assistance Commission reports on this question. The State governments also have a lot of information. The Australian Agricultural Council on 28 April this year took a decision to request the Federal Government to accelerate in conjunction with it and the industry the final phases of the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign known as BATEC. The Cattle Council of Australia followed this up with a meeting early in May and came out again with a very detailed backing of not only the IAC reports and AAC decision but also the very detailed and excellent work by the Department of Primary Industry in terms of the national planning group.

ANSWER.PARA: To answer the honourable member's question, it is opportune to take action now, but what we are talking about is an acceleration because the program is very much an ongoing one. It is exceptionally important that we proceed to the final stages of the eradication of brucellosis and tuberculosis for the sake of our export markets and in order to give our cattle industry, our meat industry, a real edge in the international market place.

The third part of the honourable gentleman's question related to buffaloes. A very expensive part of the final phase will be concerned with the virtual destruction of the feral buffalo herd. That part of the campaign is to cost about $15m but, by definition, the whole campaign in the remote areas will be exceptionally expensive. The Commonwealth's contribution to the cost of the campaign will amount to slightly less than 25 per cent thereof and will be concerned with the payment of compensation. The major part of the cost will be met by industry and by the States. However, in respect of the campaign in the Northern Territory, it is proposed that the Commonwealth meet some 75 per cent of the cost.

Tuberculosis infection in the remote areas is also exceptionally high. Perhaps we could consider some of the costs and estimates in regard to the Kimberleys, the area about which the honourable gentleman is so concerned. There are about 800,000 cattle on 110 properties, 44 of which present rather difficult problems. Of the cost of the accelerated phase of this campaign, which will proceed through 1992-some $303m-about $140m will have to be spent in the Northern Territory, the Kimberleys and North Queensland. In the Northern Territory about one and a quarter million cattle on 237 properties, of which 132 present special difficulties, are involved. In North Queensland there are 3.3 million cattle on some 3,500 properties, of which about 134 are estimated to present particular difficulties. The remainder of the funding allocated to the program will be spent on the properties and in continued testing in an effort to render the herd 100 per cent clean. The Department and the various responsible authorities are working on obtaining better test methods of detecting reactors.

As the honourable member points out, it is true that cattle do move freely throughout the continent. With the breaking of the drought in the southern States, cattle will move from Alice Springs, for example, to the south west of Western Australia, through Adelaide-

TALK.START.PARA: —Make a statement to the House.
—If honourable gentlemen opposite do not want to hear the answer I will not proceed with it.
—I remind the Minister that a request has been made that answers be kept to a reasonable length.

—I assure the House that the current program will continue to June 1984 . More than $34m has been spent on it so far this year. The Government realises how important the program is. The only delay has been that caused by the need to give the matter due consideration in a budgetary context. I point out that the former Government wiped out a $23.5m debt. We are examining the matter in the context of the Budget because of the dreadful mess that the former Government left.

—Does the Treasurer agree that the consumer price index consequence of the rise in prices and costs following last week's mini-Budget, including those related to telephone charges, superannuation, mortgages, health insurance, air fares and petrol prices in non-metropolitan areas, will increase the difficulty of restraining wage demands? Will the Treasurer inform the House whether he has taken these increases into account in making his wage forecasts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fairly minimal effects will flow from the changes set out in the May statement of economic measures, which was delivered last week. In fact, the Government was very mindful of the impacts upon the consumer price index and the subsequent effect upon inflation and upon wages. That effect would be less than 0.2 per cent. I indicate that that is a very strange question to come from a government which specialised in jacking up the CPI with its indirect taxes and charges. Indeed, if we want to look at where all the soft tax options were in the period in office of the last Government, we find that they were in areas of indirect taxation, particularly in respect of the crude oil levy, which had a massive impact upon Australian inflation in the latter part of the 1970s.

ANSWER.PARA: It was because of this easy resort to the taxing of oil, following the dramatic rise in the prices imposed by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries during 1979 and 1980, that the Fraser Government did not at any time face up to its responsibilities in terms of the sort of balance within the fiscal structure of Commonwealth outlays. That is why this Government is now in a position-given the inheritance left by the former Government in terms of the size of the Budget deficit in prospect-to look at those structural elements of outlays which will present a problem over a long period. Hence the Government's resolve in the statement last Thursday and beyond to look at some of the major structural measures, of which pensions for people aged over 70 and superannuation were but two.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the disastrous impact of low sugar prices on cane growers, sugar mills, mill employees, town businesses and towns right along the Queensland and northern New South Wales coasts? Is the Minister further aware that the end of June is a key time for the industry's finances and that decisions for Commonwealth assistance must be made as a matter of urgency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the Opposition will allow me to answer this question fully. It might show more interest in the sugar industry than it did in the beef industry. The honourable members for Herbert and Capricornia have been vitally concerned about the sugar industry. I must point out the dilatoriness with which the past Government regarded this industry. The first approach by the sugar industry to the then Government was in January 1981. It was made in respect of the domestic price formula. If something had been done then, the industry would have gained some $72m by January of this year. The industry kept approaching the past Government from then until September 1982, when the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries came to this capital and was turned away. Eventually, in November 1982, the past Government decided to have the Industries Assistance Commission report on the short term problems and later on the long term problems .

ANSWER.PARA: During the election campaign the short term report on the request for assistance came through to the then government of the day. Although I am not at liberty to say what was in that report, Mr Nixon, the past Minister, is reported as saying in Mackay during the election campaign that there was nothing in it and the Government would be following the IAC's advice. So, there was not much response from the past Government with respect to the sugar industry. As the honourable member states, the industry is in desperate trouble. It is receiving a little over one third of the money received in 1980, due to the collapse of the international sugar market. That has been caused mainly by the fact that the European Economic Community, which was a net importer of sugar in 1977, is now putting five million to seven million tonnes of sugar on the world market, and that is a world market of 20 million tonnes. The farm cash operating surplus of the industry is negative. It is getting nowhere near the cane price equivalent this year, which would get up to $234 a tonne, the amount given as the cost of production when translated from the sugar price down to the cane price. There are long term and immediate problems. These include problems of welfare, liquidity, cash flow, mills, the drought, and the International Sugar Agreement. If honourable members opposite are not interested in dealing with these matters they have no sympathy for the sugar industry on the Queensland coast.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I point out that all these interruptions, of course, affect the number of questions that can be asked.
—Perhaps I should draw my answer to a conclusion.
—It would be very wise.

—The Government is concerned about the sugar industry, unlike the Opposition which has demonstrated its approach. I have met representatives of the industry on three occasions and a submission before the Government is under active consideration. We appreciate the desperate straits the industry is in.

—Does the Prime Minister recall his promise to provide immediate reductions in income tax, his promise to retain the tax rebate for home loan payments, his promise to introduce a first home ownership asssistance scheme as 'an option to the existing deposit assistance scheme which will be retained', his promise not to increase tax on lump sum superannuation, his promise not to take money out of the weekly pay packet, his promise not to take money out of the pensioner's cheque, his promise not to abandon the Alice Springs-Darwin railway, his promise to extend desperately needed--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. Consistent with your earlier rulings, Mr Speaker, this is not a preface to a question; it is a statement.

—Order! I accept what the honourable member says, but he realises that there is no hard and fast rule on this matter and that the Leader of the Opposition, because of his position, is allowed some indulgence-although I hope he will not stretch that indulgence.

—His promise to extend desperately needed public capital works and services, his promise to continue the Government's major airport development program, his promise to provide 'a major new concession to the small businesses of this nation', his promise to reduce the price of petrol by 3c per litre, his promise to achieve fixed term four-year parliaments and his promise to retain the health insurance rebate until the introduction of Medicare? Will the Prime Minister tell the House from whom he received a mandate to break these promises?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to assure the House-although honourable members must have considerable doubt-that this question is not a Dorothy Dixer; I did not ask the Leader of the Opposition to ask this question. But it gives me a great deal of pleasure to answer the question. Yes, I remember the whole program that was put by the Australian Labor Party and through me as the Leader of the Labor Party during the last election campaign. I have very clear recollections of everything that happened in that campaign, not only the promises that were made by us but also the context in which they were made. I remind the House that it was a context in which the members opposite, then as the Government, mendaciously went around the country saying that the context in which any incoming Government would be operating would be one in which the deficit situation for 1983-84 would be about $6 billion, when at least some of them knew that that was a downright lie. I had reason to point out to the House earlier this week that at least the shadow Treasurer, deceitful as he was, has been honest enough or manful enough since the election to say: 'I am going to cop the blame'.

ANSWER.PARA: The question has been asked as to whether I remember what happened during the campaign and the promises that were made. I remember them clearly and I remember the fact that not once during the campaign did the present Leader of the Opposition say one word to dissociate himself from the deception that was then practised. I also have a clear recollection of something else that I said in the campaign. I remember that it was in this city on 2 March, at the National Press Club, when I was giving the National Press Club address and then giving answers to questions. On 2 March at the National Press Club, Dr Summers, of the Australian Financial Review, addressed a question to me, which I remember, in respect of these promises. She said: 'Mr Hawke, should you get government, what if you find, in respect of the situation that has been put to you by the present Government, and put to the people of Australia, that the Government has not been telling the truth? What will that do in respect of these promises?' Before 5 March I responded to the question about these promises that are listed by the Leader of the Opposition. I said unequivocally to Dr Summers, and to the people of Australia: 'If I and the incoming Government find that indeed we and the people of Australia have been deceived by the Government and we inherit a larger deficit than that of which the Government has been telling us, then we shall have to review our program'. Before 5 March, in response to such a question in regard to all those promises, I made a clear statement on behalf of the Australian Labor Party that we would have to review all those promises in our program if we found that we and the Australian people had been deceived. I finally refer to that part of the question of the Leader of the Opposition when he asked where we got the mandate from. We got a clear and unequivocal mandate from the people of Australia on 5 March in the context of what I have said and made clear on the Wednesday of that last week, that if we--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. In fact I seek your advice. Under the Standing Orders surely there is something that insists that the Prime Minister acts honestly and not like a used car salesman.

—Order! I remind the honourable member that the Chair is conscious of the Standing Orders and one of those Standing Orders provides that points of order should be points of order and not frivolous, or action may be taken.

—I conclude by saying that we got the overwhelming mandate that we did on 5 March because we were honest and our opponents were dishonest. That is why for election after election from here on, while the Opposition continues as it is now, to be dishonest, and we continue to be honest, we will continue to win.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES BOARD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I table the annual report of the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board for 1981-82. I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The report dated 30 June 1982 is addressed to my predecessor, the Honourable David Thomson, M.C. It covers the first full year of operation under the amendments to the 1976 Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The retiring chairman, Dr Walter L.
