QUESTION.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 5 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. Can he say whether problems are being experienced by members of the Defence Forces, when transferred interstate, as a result of differing motor drivers' licence requirements in each State.
2. If so, has any action been taken to examine the feasibility of uniform drivers' licences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Members of the Defence Forces and their immediate families experience very few problems with the minor differences in motor drivers' licence requirements in each State, when they are transferred interstate.

Each State and Territory, other than New South Wales, treats all Defence Forces personnel movements as being of a temporary nature and only requires a change of drivers' licence if the expiry date falls due during the temporary posting to that State or Territory.

New South Wales differs in that all postings are considered permanent except for Defence personnel attending courses of instruction and who will be returning to their home State, irrespective of the duration of the course. New South Wales requires Defence personnel transferred from interstate to immediately obtain a New South Wales licence unless they are on temporary posting.

2. A proposal for uniform driver licence classifications to apply throughout Australia is to be discussed by the Australian Transport Advisory Council (ATAC) when next it meets in July this year. Other aspects of uniform licensing arrangements are under consideration in ATAC's Technical Committees.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keogh Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 5 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the weekly hire and operation costs of the dredges used for the sand dumping on the reclamation work for the new Brisbane Airport.

(2) Can he say what action had been initiated by the former Prime Minister or any Minister of the former Government, between election in December 1975 and defeat at the recent election to support any proposal to re-sand the Wynnum- Manly foreshores by (a) making those dredges available, (b) proposing to meet fully or partially the cost, (c) seeking agreement with the Queensland Government and the Brisbane City Council to undertake the work and, (d) considering any proposal of this kind for re-sanding.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Dredging and reclamation work at Brisbane Airport has been carried out on a lump sum contract basis. No weekly costs are available. Average costs over the duration of the work are estimated at $600 000 per week.

(2) The Wynnum-Manly foreshores are vested for management in the Brisbane City Council and any maintenance or replenishment is entirely its responsibility. The Brisbane City Council has made no formal approaches to the Australian Government with beach re-sanding proposals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 12 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government support the policy, approved on 5 May 1983 by the Congress of the United States of America, of a US/Soviet freeze on nuclear weapons; if so , will the Government indicate its support for such a freeze to President Reagan .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The United States House of Representatives on 4 May passed a resolution by a vote 278-149 calling on the President to negotiate 'a mutual and verifiable freeze and reductions in nuclear weapons' with the freeze to be revoked if it were not followed by negotiated arms reductions 'within a reasonable, specified period of time'. It is understood that this proposal is still to be considered by the United States Senate.

In principle the Government is attracted to the concept of a nuclear freeze as a means of achieving reductions of nuclear forces. In considering the case for a nuclear freeze however it is important that the result be mutually agreed and verifiable. A freeze at excessively high levels of armaments which did not look forward to reductions in those levels would be likely to perpetuate anxiety and uncertainty about risks of nuclear war. A freeze which gave advantage to one side would not contribute to a stable peace.

The Government will make known its approach on arms control and disarmament questions to the United States Government during the visit to Washington by the Prime Minister in June. There will be a further opportunity for high level consultations with the United States during the ANZUS Council meeting in Washington in July.
